5852: Dark Hatchling.author: WhiteWizard42
5852: Dark Hatchling.text_parsed: Tavaritz - No, if they played Deathlace, the creature would become an illegal target and the whole ability would be countered. The only reason I can think of for it to say "this turn" would be if you made it indestructible in response, then someone tried to destroy it next turn. But indestructibility wasn't introduced until 4 years after this card, so ... /shrug

5858: Carpet of Flowers.author: yyukichigai
5858: Carpet of Flowers.text_parsed:
Green color-hate has always been where the most abuseable cards come from. Case in point: this card and Seedtime.

After using something like Stormtide Leviathan or Quicksilver Fountain, this can handily pay for an Inkwell Leviathan that will almost certainly be unblockable since, in a bit of odd coincidence, your opponents will have at least a few Islands on the board.

@ttian: Helix Pinnacle is a really good way to use up any mana left over from this, and probably the easiest. Lots of other options, too: Dark Depths, Clockwork Dragon, Fungal Bloom (if you were given green mana), Gemstone Array, Magma Mine (my fav), Iceberg, or just about anything that levels.

5858: Carpet of Flowers.author: jfre81
5858: Carpet of Flowers.text_parsed:
Note it says "up to X" not simply "X" so at the time, with the mana burn rule still in play, you could add only what you could use to your pool.

I like the idea of splashing this in a blue merfolk deck with Lord of Atlantis and Stormtide Leviathan. Not too hard to get one green mana. Prophetic Prism can do it without giving up card advantage. Magical Hack can also change it from "islands" to whatever is most expedient for you at the time.

5863: Morphling.author: Paleopaladin
5863: Morphling.text_parsed:
I'm soooo going to get flamed and voted down for this, but...

The game has passed this guy by. Over the years MtG has become more about creature power and less about everything else. For the same CMC, I'd rather play Djinn of Wishes, Belltower Sphinx, or Serra Sphinx.

This guy dies to bolt and most removal if you didn't leave a mana open to save him. So against ,, and you're probably waiting till turn 6 to play him if your opponent has cards in hand. You could argue then, that this guys' spot is in your deck's CMC slot. Then he has to be compared to cards like Guile, Sphinx of Jwar Isle, and Sphinx Magosi. He doesn't nearly come out ahead in those comparisons.

He's among many classic creatures from the past like Juzám Djinn, Nightmare, and Serra Angel. All cards that are still very playable, but are not the apocalyptic menaces they once were. 3.5/5 since some decent equipments/enchantments could still make him a very dangerous character, but he definitely isn't "Superman" or "God in Cardboard Form" anymore.

5863: Morphling.author: BloodJunkie
5863: Morphling.text_parsed:
5/5
Always was and always will be a great card.
I used to play mono blue control back in Urza days and this guy was my killing tool.
Though I agree, while he was once "God in cardboard form", he is now simply a powerful five mana investment. Unfortunately Wizards upped the ante and Morphling can't compete with a couple of the newer creatures. (Quicksilver Gargantuan being the most recent. Stormtide Leviathan, Chronozoa and Deep-sea Kraken are also cool.)
Personally what I do now is play a mono blue artifact control. My replacement for good old Superman was Master of Etherium. Keep in mind I also have 4 Blinkmoth Nexus, 4 Mishra's Factory and 4 Seat of the Synod.
Here's how it works:
The Master's p/t is based on the amount of artifacts you control. If he's alone on the field, he is 1/1. Synod is an artifact and an island at the same time. So each one in play makes him more powerful. Also the Masters buff each other. So the more you have the better they are. The Nexus and Factory can turn into artifact creatures for one mana. Therefore, to buff my Master, I simply turn my lands into creatures. Even with only 1 of each of the lands and only 1 Master (which I usually pull way more due to excessive card drawing), the Master would be a 4/4 and you also get a 2/2 flier and another 3/3 buddy, at an amazingly low cost of 2 mana. Needless to say, the more Masters and land I pull, the crazier things get. All the while it is still fundamentally a control deck. I personally noted that I kill alot faster with this combo than with a single Morphling. Or even 2 - 4 Morphlings. And its alot easier to pull the combo than it sounds.
All in all, I still give Morphling a 5/5. I love this card. He was amazing for his time. He's still great now. But sadly he's not the God he used to be.

5863: Morphling.author: Necrokeryx
5863: Morphling.text_parsed:
It's not a bad creature at all, but definitely overrated now. If they had kept the damage on the stack rule, this would have been a 5/6 for five mana that can have flying, vigilance and shroud for 7UUU a turn. As it is now it can swing for five with shroud on the sixth turn if you pay 2U into it, and it will be chump-blocked by any ground creature out there unless you pay one U more, and then you have to assume they'll have no fliers. Then next turn if you want to untap it to block anything with more than 3 power you have to spend at least 1U. Spending so much mana on one creature really messes up your mana curve and you can't do much else with your turn other than attack, or block.

This seems like a classic example of people trying to seem like experienced players by blindly following what everyone else says. Personally I don't believe Morphling is worth the 10$. I know it's not the best creature in the game, but I would use it if it was maybe 1$ or something.

5863: Morphling.author: Kryptnyt
5863: Morphling.text_parsed:
Today's power levels have caught up to and exceeded this guy. I don't even see people play him in commander games on MTGO. A combination of M10 combat damage rulings and subsequent highly playable finishers for blue decks have taken down what was once a nightmare to play against.
Mono-U control is nearly an impossible build in standard right now, when once it ruled the format. But U/X Aggro Control is very strong, with cards like Delver of Secrets giving them the business much quicker than Morphling ever could. Planeswalkers represent the new standard of finisher for control decks that Morphling once represented.

5863: Morphling.author: Cyberium
5863: Morphling.text_parsed:
Morphling is no longer the offensive juggernaut it was, but Superman is more than just an offensive juggernaut. It never was a one-trick pony.

1) Ability to untap to many is just vigilance, but it combos with many other cards in the game. Anything requires multiple tapping or an untap creatures could use this ability. Quicksilver Dagger, for example, Morphling could pew pew better than any Sphinx.

2) Shroud keeps Morphling neigh unkillable, and since it's not a permanent shroud it's pretty much like a semi-hexproof, allow you to enchant or equip it, a benefit sets Superman aside from other shroud creatures.

3) Ability to block almost any creature, with old rules you could kill attackers without dying. While its offense is dampened, Morphling's blocking power never fails, it can still attack and untap itself for defense.

People are right when they say Morphling is no longer as powerful, damaged by both M10 rules and power creeping, but that doesn't make it weak. It deserves at least 4/5 in a regular player's hand, and 4.5+ for those who know how to use it.

5865: Acridian.author: Cactmoore
5865: Acridian.text_parsed:
In my opinion, this is the way that Echo should work in its simplest, purest form. We have a reasonably useful creature for a discounted cost on the grounds that you are paying the remaining cost a turn later. Of course, if you don't pay it, the "repo men" send it to your graveyard. No fancy alternative costs, no "it is better to let the creature die so its 'leaves battlefield' ability can trigger". Just a creature you pay for in instalments.
On its own merits, though, this isn't a terribly good card: if it had Reach or one of those "this creature cannot be blocked except by ____" abilities, I think it would be more flavourful and more useful. Consider that for the same CMC (albeit paid on one turn instead of over 2) you can get a Giant Spider (3G cost), which is a 2/4 with Reach instead of vanilla.
Anyway, I find the card reasonably interesting, but not great on its own merits.

Echo was such a terrible idea on creatures like this -- ones that lack haste or an 187 ability.

This is a card where the "dies to removal" argument is relevant. You spend your second turn playing this creature, and then you lose your ability to make a full third-turn drop by paying for your creature who has yet to do anything! Your opponent can just watch you sacrifice your own tempo on your third turn, then off this stupid card with a Terror. That knocks an aggro deck right on it's ass.

7168: Windfall.author: tcollins
7168: Windfall.text_parsed:
Absolutely brutal in an aggressive affinity deck. For example using it in an affinity deck you could have something like this if you play first:

Turn 1: Darksteel Citadel, Ornithopter, Springleaf Drum. Drop a Mox Opal (with metalcraft activated), drop a Frogmite for free. Exile a Simian Spirit Guide for {R} , then tap the Ornithopter and Springleaf Drum for {R} , tap the Mox Opal for {U} and cast Windfall...

You draw seven cards and pass the turn with huge board advantage on your opponent. Next turn having access to {3} mana (assuming one of the seven cards you drew was a land) and you can begin dropping things like Arcbound Ravager and Atog.
7168: Windfall.text_posted:

Turn 1: [autocard]Darksteel Citadel[/autocard], [autocard]Ornithopter[/autocard], [autocard]Springleaf Drum[/autocard]. Drop a [autocard]Mox Opal[/autocard] (with [i]metalcraft[/i] activated), drop a [autocard]Frogmite[/autocard] for free. Exile a [autocard]Simian Spirit Guide[/autocard] for {R} , then tap the [autocard]Ornithopter[/autocard] and [autocard]Springleaf Drum[/autocard] for {R} , tap the [autocard]Mox Opal[/autocard] for {U} and cast [autocard]Windfall[/autocard]...

You draw seven cards and pass the turn with huge board advantage on your opponent. Next turn having access to {3} mana (assuming one of the seven cards you drew was a land) and you can begin dropping things like [autocard]Arcbound Ravager[/autocard] and [autocard]Atog[/autocard].

7817: Curfew.author: Aaron_Forsythe
7817: Curfew.text_parsed:
Aaron's Random Card Comment of the Day #36, 11/15/10

I like this card's design quite a bitâit reads simply, but it gives you a lot to think about and it lends itself to some very clever plays. Note that it was designed and released under pre-Sixth Edition rules, so it works in combat currently essentially the same way it did when it was first printed.

My only hesitation with reusing it is that, one, it will never replace simpler targeted effects like Unsummon in Core Sets, and two, its name is a huge barrier to reprinting it in other expansions. "Curfew" sounds like exactly what the card depicts it to beâa time for children to be in bed, not a spell concept that can be dropped easily into any world. So it gets passed over.

Looking through Urza's Saga, it surprises me just how strong that "kids in school" flavor comes throughâI was mostly oblivious to it as a player. The fact that Urza's Saga was split along color lines across five distinct places and times did not come through when I was using the cards. Perhaps I'm just dense.

Anyway, take a look at Urza's Saga blue. You'll see young Teferi in the role of Disruptive Student; Barrin, Master Wizard looking positively Dumbledore-esque; a Stern Proctor, some Academy Researchers, and an Arcane Laboratory wherein Hermetic Studying could be done; the Tolarian Academy itself; and my favorite, Show and Tell. Curfew fits right in!

7817: Curfew.author: Internet_decks_lame
7817: Curfew.text_parsed:
Surprised at the low rating for such a good card, especially in legacy format with so many reanimator decks, progenitus, and other single creature combos. Not to mention... some decks might find the negative to be a very effective positive allowing a critical creature save against an opponent's removal while at the same time bouncing one of their creatures causing potential delay. Sure it doesnt match unsummon's ability to target, but wiith the right deck this card can get you card advantage and amplify delay if thats what you are looking for. Combine with Stingscourger for a potential 3 bounces on the same target, and if you add Gilded Drake to the mix... why edict or plow when you can do little bounce, steal the animated monster, slap him with it, and/or bounce your drake. Each card costing 2 mana or less... sounds good to me... and if your a control freak add Aether Membrane and Rage Nimbus so after stealing your opponents nasties with Gilded, force the drake to attack with Nimbus' effect and look! The backstabbing drake runs into the membrane and poof back to your hand. Now its ready to steal the next creature and run into the membrane all over again. Hmmm... maybe its not a backstabber after all...


5/5

8445: Recantation.author: Mode
8445: Recantation.text_parsed:
@izzet_guild_mage This cycle of enchantments is slow as molasses, but what bugs me most about them is that they require you to pay mana for the activation cost. They don't have shroud, so you better keep that mana open at all times since you don't want your opponent to disenchant (or bounce) them when they have a considerable amount of counters on them.

And as Tiggurix said, their effects are powerful, but the mana cost for them (or at least Recantation) seems to high for them to be useful. Even if you play this on turn five and wait until turn eight, you'll just pay if you to bounce a mere three creatures (with barely any surprise, either).
Basically even if you kept one of your islands untapped on turn six and seven...

8446: Discordant Dirge.author: Mode
8446: Discordant Dirge.text_parsed:
Agreed, you'll rarely have any good use of this card.
Immediately casting Fugue instead will do a far better job most of the time since your opponent likely won't have four or more cards in hand by the time you cast this for five and wait four more turns.
I can't imagine they excessively playtested this card. Or they always played against a blue deck with heavy card advantage, i'm not quite sure.
Anyways, i think getting 3/3 beasts, returning permanents, destroying lands or even destroying artifacts and/or enchantments is far more useful than letting your opponent discard cards - because that's what the other colors' cards of that cycle do.
Actually the entire cycle is overcosted, but when regarding Fugue you'll notice that you won't find a card which either lets you put three 3/3 tokens into play, return three permanents or destroy three lands.
I think the casting cost of this card could easily have been dropped to in order to make it useful.

8447: Rumbling Crescendo.author: Saraneth888
8447: Rumbling Crescendo.text_parsed: Can sometimes be a great 'don't screw with me' card in EDH, if you're running a slightly politically oriented deck and happen to be in red. If nobody has enchantment removal in hand when it comes down (or soon after), it can really turn into a card that just says: "don't attack me or kill my stuff, or I'll eat half your land"... though its terribly slow speed, and the fact that it's a really awful topdeck both mean that it is only decent at best, even in the decks that want to run things like that.

The problem with those guys was that you usually had to attack with them to get them tapped and let you use the ability, but they were usually too small to do that without them being blocked by something bigger. So this lets you tap them to enable the ability while also pinging, then untap them for their other ability, over and over again until you run out of mana. These are the kinds of things that make a Johnny smile.

8801: Pit Trap.author: tcollins
8801: Pit Trap.text_parsed: The real problem with cards like these that are defensive-minded triggers that you can pop when you feel like it, is that they are not nearly as effective when your opponent is aware that they are there. Allowing them to prepare for it and adapt accordingly. This, is the main reason that instant-speed is always better than sorcery-speed. That being said, it's an older card that has not aged well, considering all the removal out there for {4}..although for removal its instant-counterparts are generally better, there is alot to be said for colourless removal that gets around creatures with nasty protection, such as Pristine Angel and could hit Emrakul if you figured out a way to get rid of his flying..

8808: Lifeline.author: Erkusandor
8808: Lifeline.text_parsed: I've got a question about this card: WHEN exactly has the 2nd creature to be on the battlefield? When the 1st one dies or when it is returned from the graveyard? Example: I got 2 creatures. I sacrifice the first, then the second. What happens? Will the first creature come back since at the time it got to the graveyard there was a 2nd creature, or will it not come back because when the triggered effect is about to resolve there is no 2nd creature anymore on the battlefield?
8808: Lifeline.text_posted: I've got a question about this card: WHEN exactly has the 2nd creature to be on the battlefield? When the 1st one dies or when it is returned from the graveyard? 8808: Lifeline.author: Teufelhunden0311
8808: Lifeline.text_parsed: @ERKUSANDOR the card resolves at the end of the turn. So to answer your question NO! If all you have is 2 creatures you can not sacrifice one and then bring it back and then sacrifice the other and also bring that one back because when you sacrificed both of them they both wouldn't return to play until the end of the turn and since you sacrificed both there wouldn't be a creature there to trigger the effect of the card, BUT. . . . if your OPPONENT has a creature out it still applies because the card says "A" creature not specifying one of "YOUR" creatures. I can see how the wording conflicts with it's intended effect. I imagine this card has sparked quite a debate amongst Magic players believe me as a person that plays this card in an Eldrazi deck (I own every Eldrazi). To answer the question about token creatures. . . no they can not be returned to the battlefield since a token creature once removed can not return because technically it never hits the graveyard.
8808: Lifeline.text_posted: @ERKUSANDOR the card resolves at the end of the turn. So to answer your question NO! I can see how the wording conflicts with it's intended effect. 8808: Lifeline.author: TheLibertinistic
8808: Lifeline.text_parsed:
Thank god for Oracle rewordings. I know that basically all design know-how checked out for Urza's block, but this card is kind of a cake-taker. As worded, its effect makes no sense (Do I return my opponents creature's from my graveyard? Does that change anything?). The exact mechanics of the delayed trigger are totally obscure (does it check for someone holding the Lifeline at end of turn or at death?). All exacerbated by the weird indefinite reference on "a creature" that seems to imply you return the Line-holder from your graveyard to play at end of turn (but only your graveyard). Even its interaction with something as basic as wrath effects is somewhat non-obvious.

Also, part of an awkward vogue for symmetrical effects that really never felt logical. (See also: Thran Weaponry, the only equipment that also arms your opponents.) Why am I saving my opponent's creatures, again? And why does the card, as written, all /them/ to be holding my Lifeline?

All in all, a cluster of terrible decisions. 0/5

SIde Note: Still a fun though hateful option to make EDH prison decks with the Kamigawa Spirit Dragons. The white one is particularly awful.

8808: Lifeline.author: foxinnaboxphenna
8808: Lifeline.text_parsed:
"The card clearly states "into graveyard", but the details say "into graveyard from battlefield", yet there is no offical rulings stating that it has to be from the battlefield, so, which is it?"

"The Oracle text under the Details section is official." <--True.

Also, even if it didn't specify "from the battlefield," it would work the same, because it says "creature," not "creature card." A card can only be a "creature" when it is on the battlefield; in any other zone, it's called a "creature card."

8808: Lifeline.author: Dreznin
8808: Lifeline.text_parsed:
@foxinaboxphenna - Gatherer shows the card text as it would appear today in the Details section. At the time it was printed, it was thought that the original text was clear enough - they have since realized it wasn't and with rulings it has been updated to:

Whenever a creature dies, if another creature is on the battlefield, return the first card to the battlefield under its owner's control at the beginning of the next end step.

The creature has to die, so it has to first be in play. Thankfully, the Gatherer/Oracle rewording has greatly improved the ability to decipher how this card works.

For lots of fun, build a deck around this card using Echo creatures with come into play abilities (Deranged Hermit and Goblin Marshal being my favorites to combo with this) and enjoy. I also run it in a self-destruct Zubera deck running things like Spawning Pit to allow me to trigger the Zubera effects every turn. Getting creative with this card can lead to lots of fun - even if your enemy gets the benefit to.

8808: Lifeline.author: songmage
8808: Lifeline.text_parsed:
4/5 because regardless of the deck you're playing, if your opponent sees it in play, they know what target#1 will be.

Two things prevented this thing from becoming stupid-valuable; 1: mana cost, 2: the fact that the wording was re-envisioned means that you will have to explain it every time it hits the table.

For everybody that says "OMG WHY DID YOU CHANGE WORDING TO BE GLOBAL," I have a hard time believing that it was meant to be anything else. It has two operative words that indicate one or the other: "a" and "your."

If they changed it to "whenever a creature is put into YOUR graveyard," it would have exclusively meant one-sided. If they changed it to "return that creature card from THAT PLAYER's graveyard," it would have meant global. It could be either/or, but the statement as-is makes no sense at all. A clarification was required.

Saga already has many broken cards. All they have to do to keep this card a super combo builder, plus not make it stupid-broken is to make it global.

Besides, why not pair this thing up with slate of ancestry? I mean really, this thing has so many cheap combos that everybody should own 4 just for the "kudos" factor of having found another creative way to make this card do something terrible.

8809: Noetic Scales.author: Justice1337
8809: Noetic Scales.text_parsed:
I use this a lot in EDH. My Doran Infect deck has it to abuse the low-power/high-toughness theme. It virtually never affects me, and will always either bounce a few creatures or deter everyone else from playing certain ones. I use it in my Damia Discard/Stax deck also, because it's designed to drain everyone else's hand, and in that setting it bounces virtually all of the creatures they decide to play.

Very powerful, seldom seen card. Making symmetrical effects asymmetrical is the bread and butter of multiplayer control.

8810: Umbilicus.author: Blue_mana
8810: Umbilicus.text_parsed:
@Superllama12 and @Duskdale_Wurm

The reason why the name umbilicus fits this ability perfectly, is because of commercal diving.
Commercial divers gets their air through tubes called umbillicals. If a diver stays submerged for to long he, or she would get decompression sickness (DCS), so in order to prevent this the diver needs to return to the surface after a given amount of time.

However, the diver could stay under water for almost as long as he wants, but the duration of the dive decides how long he must have a 'decompression stop' to release nitrogen (nitrogen causes DCS) from his body. The duration of the dive, and depth, also increases the chanses for DCS.

If you wanted to add that option to this card it could be:

During each players' upkeep, that player pays 2 life, returns a permanent he or she controls to owner's hand or exiles target nonland permanent he or she controls with X time counters where X is the converted mana cost of the permanent and it gains suspend.

sorry for the late info.

Anyways on card! The creature in this cards artwork is weird and scary, yet awesome at the same time. I kinda wish there was a token card (I know it doesn't make tokens) or a stand alone version. Other then that. That card is kind of poo. Unless you have 1 life. Then a 4/4 flying Horror for 3!!!

8817: Lurking Evil.author: OpenSeasonNoobs
8817: Lurking Evil.text_parsed:
@John-Bender
You can pay costs as many times as you would like. The ability will go on the stack and it will become a 4/4 creature as many times as the ability resolves. It is not a split second, abilities activate at instant speed, so you could pay the cost to drop yourself to 1 life then sac a Tainted Sigil to gain 19. Also, you could sac the tainted sigil, then in response to THAT sac, you could pay the cost so many times it will drop you to 1, sac a 2nd tainted sigil, repeat the process. So, time for lol combos.

Boon Reflection with the TS will make it so you can pay the cost to down yourself to 1, sac TS, gain 38 life. Do so 4 times and...
1st time, go up to 39.
2nd time, go down 38, add the 19 from the original, go up to 115
3rd time, go down 114, add the 57 lost previously, go up to 343
4th time, go down 342, add the 171 lost previously, go up to 514. Oh, btw, did I mention that Sanguine Bond you played earlier? Good job kiddo, glad you're on top of this.
Grand total lifegain, 38+114+342+513=1007. If you haven't won at this point... Well, let's just add some more exponential growth to the equation.
Assume you've played 4 BR's and 4 SB's.
First time, you gain 19*4 life, that is 76 lifegain, 304 life loss for your opponent. See where I'm going with this?
2nd time :: go down 75, gain 75*4+19+1=320 Life, 319*4+304=1580 Total life lost by opponent thus far.
3rd time :: go down 319, gain 319*4+75+19+1=1371 Life, 1370*4+1580= 7060 Total life lost by opponent thus far
4th time :: go down 1370, gain 1370*4+319+75+19+1= 5894 Life, 5893*4+7060=30632.

So you are at 5894 life now, and you have caused your opponent to lose over 30k life. Hmm... I think just because of the theorycrafting involved, I must give this card a 5/5. BTW, I have a way of making this combo work in a real deck that I am not posting. Sorry.

Edit:: You would need only one Lurking Evil out to do this, I don't know if I made that clear or not...

BTW, I love it when people comment on amazing combo cards with "OMG THIS KARD IS SO USELESS!" Thanks for making standard so easy a down syndrome vegetable could win with it, Jund/Vamps ftw!!!

8817: Lurking Evil.author: XTwistedsoulX
8817: Lurking Evil.text_parsed:
I honestly don't see why this is rated so low. Let's look at this further shall we?
Say your playing suicide black. Likey you've lowered your life quite a bit near the end with all your carnophage and foul imp nonsense going on (if you use those, I ran em.) So half of low life aint gonna be much. 4 is 2. 6 is 3 ect. A 4/4 flyer for only 3 black is not that bad. It can wait on the sidelines as a finisher. Not that bad and definatley a brave play so you get bragging rights. Add to this the fact that it can be activated as an instant...might hold of an attacker and will be ready to swing next turn.
Obviously you dont wanna do this if your at 20, but that's not what this card is for. It's a finisher. Heck, I'd pay 10 life if it ment I got the win now that I think about it. Sure it has weaknesses (What creature doesn't) but a savvy player knows when and when not to use this.
Look at Phyrexian Negator. Theres another high risk powerhouse! The lurking evil has the same mana cost. You get a slightly smaller, and harder to block force. Negator gets rated high and the lurking evil dont? For shame!

8817: Lurking Evil.author: blurrymadness
8817: Lurking Evil.text_parsed:
Easier to play around than Negator..
It's a 4/4 Flyer for 3; it's gonna make you pay a hefty price!

-Consider that it plays around Tainted Aether and other "cast creature" or "creature ETB" effects and is a creature on the board only when you want it to be.

-Curves nicely into 4-mana boardwipes so you have the only critter on the board!

-Costs minimal life in the late game; and plays favorably with a large variety of cards.

-Consider that this is a finisher that can avoid sorcery speed removal for a turn while nigh-guaranteeing 4-damage downrange. If this were {R}{R}{R}; it'd see play in burn (especially after Flame Rifting yourself..)

-This card is black; if you didn't notice. This is how black works. You craft a huge advantage for yourself (Tombstalker style finisher) by playing around a potentially huge drawback.

-It's also instant speed mind you. See a big flyer barreling towards you T3/T4? Turn this guy into a 4/4 in response and eat it!

8819: Titania's Boon.author: OmegaSerris
8819: Titania's Boon.text_parsed:
@Kryptnyt

It was exactly intended. Wizards focuses on either +1 or -1 counters in each set to minimize the interaction of the two. Just look at the last few sets:

Lorywyn/Morningtide: +1/+1 (Reinforce)
Shadowmoor/Eventide: -1/-1 (Wither/Persist)
Shards of Alara: +1/+1 (Devour)
Zendikar: +1/+1 (Multikicker)
Scars of Mirrodin: -1/-1 (Infect)
Innistrad: +1/+1 (Morbid/Undying)

I think it was MaRo himself that said they will never have a set with cards that generate both types of counters because it can be confusing to newer players (the reason they seem to do anything anymore... -_-) and it is simpler to just stick to one.

8820: Endless Wurm.author: adrian.malacoda
8820: Endless Wurm.text_parsed:
Angelic destiny doesn't replace rancor. Rancor triggers when Rancor dies, not enchanted creature. Angelic Destiny triggers when the creature itself dies. With Rancor you can sac Rancor to pay for Endless Wurm's upkeep and keep bringing it back. You can't do that with Angelic Destiny.

Isn't that overkill, anyway? With Rancor he's still a 11/9 trampler. I don't really see why you'd need first strike or flying on that.

@talcumpowder0046: Fastbond is banned or restricted in every format. It's like Strip Mine vs Wasteland. Strip Mine is the stronger card, but because it's banned/restricted, Wasteland is the more valuable one.

8823: Exploration.author: blurrymadness
8823: Exploration.text_parsed:
This and burgeoning are both great. Unsure why burgeoning is *that* much cheaper though. I often use burgeoning to get out my double-mana lands (ravnica bounce lands or depletion lands) to get extra ramp. You only need that little extra boost to be 2-3 turns ahead of your opponent and those lands give you relative card advantage compared to your mana base and no tap penalty if dropped on the op's turn.

Yeah, this is usually better, but still, it's not often relevant after 2-3 land ramps. I actually may prefer Gaea's Balance for the extra temp ramp it gives.

Legacy Landfall aggro?:
T1: Forest, this, Plains, Steppe Lynx
T2: Mountain, another land, bloodbraid elf

Attack for 7, possible 11 if you cascade into something like assault strobe or colossal might

Also, fetch lands would speed it all up as well.

8846: Endoskeleton.author: DoctorKenneth
8846: Endoskeleton.text_parsed:
Generally, most skeletons are internal. One would hope. Perhaps they should have gone for a Mesoskeleton.

The art seems to be displaying some kind of external armour, so, again, some discrepancy. Anyway, this is another of the many precursors to Equipment. Generally, however, these psuedo-equipment cards are overcosted for their effect. Compare Slagwurm Armor. Running modern equipment is generally a better idea then these older prototypes- more interactions, obviously, with regards to pro-Equipment cards, among many other benefits.

So, yeah. Nothing much to see here.

8865: Phyrexian Colossus.author: Equinox523
8865: Phyrexian Colossus.text_parsed: It's easy to forget that this was once a really powerful rare. It punished chump blocking and often forced unfavorable blocks if the opponent didn't have the life to take a hit, and just some utility creatures hanging out. It also potentially 3-for-1-ed opponents if they didn't have removal, and if you slapped on a Rancor from the same block, you were in for some real carnage. The drawback was easily worked around with things like Voltaic Key and Seeker of Skybreak. With all the cheap mana available (Tolarian Academy? Gaea's Cradle?) this could potentially be barreling in for 8 damage very, very early.
8865: Phyrexian Colossus.text_posted: It's easy to forget that this was once a really powerful rare. 8867: Fault Line.author: Ligerman30
8867: Fault Line.text_parsed: I've cast this card for x = 30 and then copied it ... lulzy. This Earthquake and Molten Disaster are all pretty much the same card. Earthquake is the cheapest, this is an instant and Molten Disaster they can't respond to. Molten Disaster is probably the nastiest of the 3 but, this is nice because it's instant speed and instant speed sweepers are really good, you can hold mana and kill the creatures they would be playing after the effect during enter combat or eot. Not much else to say. Rolling Earthquake is the best of this type of effect (it kills fliers too) but, that card is stupid expensive. Also, chain reaction and blasphemous act are better if you just want to blow up the world. This is better for OTK shenannigans.

8870: Dragon Blood.author: ICEFANG13
8870: Dragon Blood.text_parsed: A +1/+1 counter makes a -1/-1 counter disappear and so will the +1/+1, basically they both go away. If you put 2 +1/+1s on a creature with 1 -1/-1 counter it will be left with a +1/+1 counter
8870: Dragon Blood.text_posted: A +1/+1 counter makes a -1/-1 counter disappear and so will the +1/+1, basically they both go away. If you put 2 +1/+1s on a creature with 1 -1/-1 counter it will be left with a +1/+1 counter

8870: Dragon Blood.author: tavaritz
8870: Dragon Blood.text_parsed:
From Comprehensive Rules:

121.3. If a permanent has both a +1/+1 counter and a -1/-1 counter on it, N +1/+1 and N -1/-1 counters
are removed from it as a state-based action, where N is the smaller of the number of +1/+1 and -1/-1
counters on it.

8876: Worn Powerstone.text_posted: Awful card. Sol Ring, Basalt Monolith, Grim Monolith, Mana Crypt, Mana Vault, and yes, Thran Dynamo blow this out of the water because you can use it the turn you play it, so you won't be tapped out when you play this.

8876: Worn Powerstone.author: donjohnson
8876: Worn Powerstone.text_parsed:
Anyone who thinks this card is aweful simply hasnt used it properly and probably doesnt understand that getting into the game a full turn earlier can mean winning or losing. One turn is all it takes to lose, as real players already know.

The powerstone is MUCH better because you get into the game a full turn earlier, costing 3 instead of 4, and you get the SAME 2 colorless as either of those others give.
It blows thran dynamo and sisay's ring away because you end up being able to use it one full turn earlier than either of those. With thran dynamo and sisay's ring youre blowing 4 mana on turn four so its turn 5 before you even get to use it with any effectiveness.
With the worn powerstone you play turn 3 so on turn 4 you have 6 mana available.

Basalt Monolith was fine in its day, but it stinks compared to the Worn Powerstone quite frankly, because you get to use it once and then its dead weight the rest of the game, unless of course youre the type who loves throwing 3 mana away every other turn.
Grim monolith is good for one turn of acceleration, then like the Basalt, is completely useless costing even more (4 mana) to untap. Again a card for players who love throwing mana way every other turn. The same goes for Mana Vault.

Mana Crypt is an excellent card if you trust leaving yourself to the odds of a coin toss.

Sol Ring blows all other acceleration out of the water...but thats why its restricted ;)

8883: Tolarian Academy.author: jeff-heikkinen
8883: Tolarian Academy.text_parsed:
(Random card review #81)

This is one I can't say much about that isn't already in the comments somewhere. I remember a couple years before this came out, desperately looking for ways to accelerate a blue deck; almost every other colour had some form of playable fast mana, but for blue there was little short of Mox Sapphire. I soon concluded that if blue were given playable fast mana it would be too good. Then High Tide came out and, though this will come as a surprise to some, didn't get played at first. I knew it was a seriously overpowered card just waiting for the right deck to come along, but apparently its initial lack of success made WotC overconfident enough to print this beast. At least, that's the only explanation I can think of. This card was so obviously broken that its dominance also inspired Extended players to dust off their High Tides and build broken decks around those, once Tolarian Academy's inevitable banning took place.

8883: Tolarian Academy.author: Moses7365
8883: Tolarian Academy.text_parsed:
What is the reality of the game these days? Traumerei112 is right this card was made famous for the great cards that were briefly legal during its time. It was mostly used as part of a early game Braingeyser basically forcing your opponent to draw out.

As far as the restricting/banning cards I think it just limits the game as a whole. I don't really think that if this card where legal for legacy it would make decks like affinity any faster from turn 0-5, but what it would do is spawn a whole bunch of artifact based decks that have nothing to do with affinity that would be competitive with decks like Faerie/control and so on.

But wizards has been legalizing cards that people thought would never come back like Timespiral so who knows what the future will hold.

8883: Tolarian Academy.author: Bauer4Prez
8883: Tolarian Academy.text_parsed:
I think that somehow the "legendary" status of this land may have led some to believe that its power was nipped a little bit (because you can't have 4 of them in play!!!) and therefore okay to print.

I remember great multiplayer games in dorm rooms where it was a race to see who could put their academy out or much more frequently it was the cradle. Back then once a legendary land hit someone else's side of the board you would have to hold yours indefinitely. I remember elf deck and token decks packing some very slight land destruction so that if they lost the race to put the cradle on the table first they could zap yours and run amok! That was one of those funny moments, to see the face of your opponent go from utter glee to disbelief when they put gaea's cradle in play only to have it end up in the graveyard by next turn!

8883: Tolarian Academy.author: adrian.malacoda
8883: Tolarian Academy.text_parsed:
@DarthParallax

It is reserved. A shame, too. IMHO the reserved list helps ensure that sets like FtV, which are ostensibly about reprinting memorable and significant cards in the history of the game, are more lackluster than they deserved to be.

It used to be that FtV and Premium Deck/Duel Deck Series were not bound by the reserved list, too. Hence why they got away with including phyrexian negator in the Phyrexia duel deck (although they really could have chosen a better card for the coalition deck, I think) and Karn, Silver Golem in FtV Relics. When the community raised its voice about the reserved list, Wizards addressed their concerns... by tightening up the policy even more.

Apparently FtV reprints don't even affect the value of a card that much, since it's such a limited print run.

@DarthParallax

It is reserved. A shame, too. IMHO the reserved list helps ensure that sets like FtV, which are ostensibly about reprinting memorable and significant cards in the history of the game, are more lackluster than they deserved to be. 

It used to be that FtV and Premium Deck/Duel Deck Series were not bound by the reserved list, too. Hence why they got away with including [autocard]phyrexian negator[/autocard] in the Phyrexia duel deck (although they really could have chosen a better card for the coalition deck, I think) and [autocard]Karn, Silver Golem[/autocard] in FtV Relics. When the community raised its voice about the reserved list, Wizards addressed their concerns... by tightening up the policy even more.

Apparently FtV reprints don't even affect the value of a card that much, since it's such a limited print run.

8883: Tolarian Academy.author: Enelysios
8883: Tolarian Academy.text_parsed:
Gaea's Cradle doesn't cost more because it is better, the opposite actually, it costs more because it isn't restricted.

This is better than Gaea's Cradle simply because it makes blue mana, and because artifacts are better and easier to get onto the field than creatures. The cradle is great (Especially in token decks) but it doesn't do much first turn, and it is green mana acceleration, something I think we've all seen before. This card rewards you for playing the most powerful cards in the game, and accelerates blue (This and High Tide are the only halfway decent blue acceleration).

Blue isn't supposed to be fast for a reason, blue decks can answer anything in the game sans lands, and they can maintain card advantage with ease. Blue decks weakness has to be a lack of aggro and acceleration, because it is all they can't do. This card single handedly solves one of those problems.

Combos with Cloud of fairies, Sol Ring, Hurkyl's Recall, Brain Freeze and any other good card.

8895: Thran Turbine.author: intlink
8895: Thran Turbine.text_parsed: Note the 2010 updates, and note the definition of "spells". The mana from this card cannot be used to cast any spell of any kind. Casting a spell is basicly bringing it from your hand to the battlefield. Thus, the mana from this cannot be used to cast instants, creatures, etc.. However, any mana that is required of any card which is already on the battlefield can use mana from Thran Turbine, including upkeeps, echo, and abilities. Also note, mana burn is no longer a rule, therefore not using the mana gained has no ill effect. Also note that cycling is defined as an ability (702.26) and therefore is legal to use Thran Turbine mana.

8895: Thran Turbine.author: iaiji
8895: Thran Turbine.text_parsed:
You can use this card to pay suspend costs, as you don't "play the card from your hand" when you suspend it :-) Suspend rather, is a static ability of the card. The card is actually "played" when the last suspend counter is removed.

To quote the comprehensive rules:
"502.59a Suspend is a keyword that represents three abilities. The first is a static ability that functions while the card with suspend is in a player's hand. The second and third are triggered abilities that function in the removed-from-the-game zone. "Suspend N--" means "If you could play this card from your hand, you may pay and remove it from the game with N time counters on it. This action doesn't use the stack," and "At the beginning of your upkeep, if this card is suspended, remove a time counter from it," and "When the last time counter is removed from this card, if it's removed from the game, play it without paying its mana cost if able. If you can't, it remains removed from the game. If you play it this way and it's a creature, it gains haste until you lose control of it."
8895: Thran Turbine.text_posted:

To quote the comprehensive rules: 
"502.59a Suspend is a keyword that represents three abilities. The first is a static ability that functions while the card with suspend is in a player's hand. The second and third are triggered abilities that function in the removed-from-the-game zone. "Suspend N--[cost]" means "If you could play this card from your hand, you may pay [cost] and remove it from the game with N time counters on it. This action doesn't use the stack," and "At the beginning of your upkeep, if this card is suspended, remove a time counter from it," and "When the last time counter is removed from this card, if it's removed from the game, play it without paying its mana cost if able. If you can't, it remains removed from the game. If you play it this way and it's a creature, it gains haste until you lose control of it."

8895: Thran Turbine.author: Kirbster
8895: Thran Turbine.text_parsed:
This simply does too many nice little things to be overlooked. It can slash echo costs, let you cycle cards for free without fluctuator, net you a free card each turn with Well of Knowledge, play activated abilities, rack up a Gemstone Array.... It's really just another cheap artifact from Urza's block that can spit out a ton of mana repeatedly, just in a less blatant manner than Grim Monolith and Thran Turbine.

Mercenaries aren't a particularly strong race, but I find a set of Turbines can help them out a lot. It makes Molting Harpy fearsome and even Pit Raptor manageable. And if you have neither out, it can help pay for recruit costs (during your upkeep, which is a sub-optimal time to do so, but free mana is free mana.)

8908: Venomous Fangs.author: NerdyTB

8908: Venomous Fangs.author: Dabir
8908: Venomous Fangs.text_parsed:
It seems like it should have deathtouch, but it works slightly differently. Deathtouch says "Any damage to the creature is treated as if it killed it", whereas this says "Whatever the damage did, it's dead anyway." The difference is in the rulings if the damage would be enough to kill the creature without deathtouch/this. You only have to regenerate once from deathtouch, because the damage, which *was* lethal, has been removed. The killing is a property of the damage, so the damage has to still be there to kill it. From this you have to regenerate twice, because the damage being removed doesn't change the fact that it used to be there. Since damage was there at some point, this triggers and tries to destroy the victim again.

tl;dr: This forces two regenerations if the damage would normally be lethal, deathtouch would need only one.

8908: Venomous Fangs.author: TheWrathofShane
8908: Venomous Fangs.text_parsed:
One downside to this card is its NOT deathtouch. Under the new rules, you have to apply full lethal damage before you can assign trample damage or damage to another creature, in multiblocking for example. 1 point of damage is considered lethal when the creature has deathtouch. If it has this triggered ability, 1 point is not considered lethal damage unless they had 1 toughness.

So it does not combo with lure, for example.
8908: Venomous Fangs.text_posted:
One downside to this card is its NOT deathtouch. Under the new rules, you have to apply full lethal damage before you can assign trample damage or damage to another creature, in multiblocking for example. 1 point of damage is considered lethal when the creature has deathtouch. If it has this triggered ability, 1 point is not considered lethal damage unless they had 1 toughness.

So it does not combo with [autocard]lure[/autocard], for example.

4/5

Sure, this one isn't as obviously broken as the blue/green ones, but its still better than 99% of lands in the game, even if it only taps for 2 mana the turn you play it, and in a Enchantments Matter deck this taps for way beyond a measly 2 mana

5/5 Stars

9700: Electryte.author: RuscoJames

9700: Electryte.author: Mode
9700: Electryte.text_parsed:
You know what bugs me? That "it deals damage equal to its power to each blocking creature."
While the wording appears interesting, this contradictive ability doesn't do its job on a 3/3 five-drop.

It invokes a one-sided Firespout when unblocked on all blockers, and does even more damage when it gets a power boost.
But knowing that, which opponent would let this guy stay unblocked then? And its body is not a threat too hard to handle either.
If he has any creatures, he'll just keep one ready to block.
Then if you manage to actually hit your opponent because he's unable to block, he doesn't have any creatures that could be dealt damage anyways.
So you're merely left with an overcosted Hill Giant.

I thought about using this in a beast tribal deck, but aside from Fangren Pathcutter maybe (or Canopy Crawler to increase the damage) i chouldn't find any beast that would synergize with it in regards of dealing damage to the opponent while still getting a bunch of blockers that could be dealt damage to.
Maybe Nucklavee with
Assault Strobe with Distortion Strike or Shadow Rift? O_o

Oh, i concede. It's a crap rare. Wizards should just print a better version of this someday.

Come to think about it, this would be pretty interesting as an enchantment that gives the ability to all of your creatures. Probably just with 1 damage for each creature then, since there would be an increasing chance for a one-sided wrath for each unblocked creature.

9700: Electryte.author: tavaritz
9700: Electryte.text_parsed:
@Mode: If we had a creature that would do everything to win the game by itself, why would we play this game?

This is awesome creature, but to get it working we need something else also. So here are my thoughts:

1. Give it unblockability (like Whispersilk cloak) and attack with all you have. Unless your opponent blocks they are toast.

2. Put Lure on another creature you have and attack with it and this. All your opponents creatures block the one with Lure and this gets through, you lose the Lure, but is that big prize to pay.

9700: Electryte.author: sweetgab
9700: Electryte.text_parsed:
Sure, when it really works out it could be great. However, from the game balance standpoint, this really showcases how low-powered creatures were back in the day.

The consensus of designers, developers and players back then: this creature's ability is so awesome. Red usually gets a 5/4 for 3RR, but if it does something as awesome as doing a mini-board wipe every turn, it can only be a 3/3 for that cost and be a rare. Any bigger and it would just be unfair to those Serra Angels.

The reality of the metagame: Lightning Bolt. Counterspell. First turn Phyrexian Negator. Tinker me a Phyrexian Processor that makes 10/10s. Replenish me ten enchantment creatures. Tolarian Academy, I win.



Edit: when I wrote this I thought it was all their creatures. Turns out... Wow.

9702: Congregate.author: RaymondKHessel
9702: Congregate.text_parsed:
I can't rate this card a 5, even though it deserves it. It has totally upended so many multiplayer (and even 1-on-1) casual matches that I've lost count. Without even crafting a specific deck strategy to accomplish it, I've seen players gain over 100 life and this puts them well out of range of the damage a lot of decks can deal. So, izzet_guild_mage, I certainly sympathize. The fact that it's an instant compounds the problem, and its power.

That being said, life gain is not degenerate. And decks should be running sweepers of some variety. Congregate is always good for a laugh in certain situations (Player 1:"I'll create infinite squirrels." Player 2: "OK, I'll gain 2*infinite life, mark it down on the ledger.")

9846: Soul Sculptor.author: lordof1000mimes
9846: Soul Sculptor.text_parsed: I play this in one of my EDH/Commander decks and it's surprisingly versatile. Even if the effect is only temporary, it can be used to remove an attacker or blocker from combat, destroy auras enchanting a creature, make equipment fall off, shut down a bunch of different static and triggered abilities, force a player to use an activated ability prematurely, save a creature from most targeted and mass removal, and/or open a creature up to enchantment removal. Above all, my favorite part is that if you hit the biggest threat on the board, your other opponents sometimes hesitate to play their own creatures and break the effct. It might not seem like much, but if you know all the ways to use it, the thing can be a Swiss army knife of a card.

9847: Karn, Silver Golem.author: Gilder_Bairn
9847: Karn, Silver Golem.text_parsed:
ideas for Karn as a planeswalker in Scars of Mirrodin:
"Karn, the Protector"(since he was built to protect someone, idunno i'm just quoting the wikipedia page)
5 colorless mana
Starts with 4 loyalty counters
+2: target creature -X/+X and reach until the beginning of your next upkeep, where X is the creature's power.
-5: all creatures' power becomes 0 until the beginning of your next upkeep. Use this ability only before the combat phase.
-X: Imprint Karn, the Protector onto target artifact creature you control, where X is the creature's converted mana cost. (Exile Karn, the Protecter. As long as he remains exiled, the artifact gains the following effect.) That artifact creature is indestructable. If it would go to the graveyard for any reason, send Karn to the graveyard instead (the imprint effect ceases).

Yeah, I know, too complicated. Anyway, second idea:
"Karn, the Forger" (since he created the plane Mirrodin)
4 Colorless mana
starts with 3 loyalty counters
+3: imprint target artifact onto Karn.
0: target non-creature artifact becomes an artifact creature with power and toughness equal to it's converted mana cost.
-12: Put an X/X giant golem creature token into play with "Sacrifice an Artifact: regenerate this creature", where X is the total converted mana cost of all the imprinted artifacts on Karn.

That's all I got. Obviously I looooooove the Imprint mechanic.

+2: target creature -X/+X and reach until the beginning of your next upkeep, where X is the creature's power.
-5: all creatures' power becomes 0 until the beginning of your next upkeep. Use this ability only before the combat phase.
-X: Imprint Karn, the Protector onto target artifact creature you control, where X is the creature's converted mana cost. [i](Exile Karn, the Protecter. As long as he remains exiled, the artifact gains the following effect.)[/i] That artifact creature is indestructable. If it would go to the graveyard for any reason, send Karn to the graveyard instead (the imprint effect ceases).

Yeah, I know, too complicated. Anyway, second idea:
"Karn, the Forger" (since he created the plane Mirrodin)
4 Colorless mana
starts with 3 loyalty counters
+3: imprint target artifact onto Karn.
0: target non-creature artifact becomes an artifact creature with power and toughness equal to it's converted mana cost.
-12: Put an X/X giant golem creature token into play with "Sacrifice an Artifact: regenerate this creature", where X is the total converted mana cost of all the imprinted artifacts on Karn.

That's all I got. Obviously I looooooove the Imprint mechanic.

9850: Fortitude.author: TopRomen
9850: Fortitude.text_parsed:
I... Actually kinda like it. On it's own, it's still an enchantment that allows you to protect your big creature even when you are tapped out. This is green, so that shouldn't be much of a deal.

This... Could be pretty beastly in a Knight of the Reliquary deck, though. In the same colors, Land Tax seems indispensable with this card (good luck finding one though). What's great about this card, is that you can use it's effect to "regenerate" the enchanted creature whenever and as often as you want! Regenerate means that the next time the creature would die, remove damage from it, remove it from combat, etc.

Shoot, you can sacrifice all your forests when you swing to give knight and/or Terravore a nice, permanent boost.

Severly underrated, I think. This thing could be HOUSE in the right deck.

9851: Goblin Lackey.author: Gwafa_Hazid
9851: Goblin Lackey.text_parsed: Disagree with rarity comment. Cards like this aren't awesome in the sense that most rares are, they're pure utility cards, and utility cards shouldn't be put up in the highest rarities(i.e., R and MR), as it only serves to inflate the prices of these individual cards to ridiculous levels, especially when it's going to be used as much as it is. Uncommon is a good rarity for this one. It's a great card, but it simply doesn't feel powerful flavor-wise, hence the name, and that's part of what makes a good rare/mythic rare.

9851: Goblin Lackey.author: BegleOne
9851: Goblin Lackey.text_parsed:
What is up with people wanting critical synergy-type "utility" tourney staple cards to be rare? It's a 1/1 combo enabler for 1. It should NOT be rare. How powerful a card is should have no bearing on rarity; rarity should only be used to balance limited play between necessary cards and oddball niche build-around-me cards. Commons should fit into most anything of that color, uncommons require a bit more deck specialization and rares should encourage building around. Goblin Lackey is a quintessential uncommon.

And if it was rare, it'd cost $40-50 instead of the $15-20 it does now.

9856: Barrin, Master Wizard.text_parsed: I give him a 3.5/5. The only time I have used him effectively is in a desperate situation. Usually late game, you can sacrifice a bunch of lands and clear your opponents side of their four or five best creatures at once, and then attack to win. You can even sac Barrin to himself. Barrin has won me games, but only as a last ditch effort. Which is why I like him, he can be sort of an ace-in-the-hole that no one expects until its too late. Don't underestimate his power.

9856: Barrin, Master Wizard.author: ChumleyX
9856: Barrin, Master Wizard.text_parsed:
The Barrin is truly legendary, an MVP in one of my best decks -- so amazing that I included three copies. What makes him so good is that you can use his ability immediately (and use it on himself in a pinch).

Here's the deck build -- an original / creation of mine:

GIX TRICKS

CREATURES (15)
3x Barrin, Master Wizard
4x Aven Riftw@tcher
4x False Prophet
4x Archon of Justice

OTHER SPELLS (22)
4x Claws of Gix
4x Perilous Research
4x Hatching Plans
4x Ichor Wellspring
2x Mycosynth Wellspring
2x Reins of Power
2x Spine of Ish Sah

LANDS (23)
7x Island
6x Plains
4x Tundra
2x Hallowed Fountain
2x Flooded Strand
2x Sejiri Refuge
1x Flagstones of Trokair
1x Karakas

You can substitute other less expensive dual land variants for the ones I included. In addition, the Flagstones of Trokair and Karakas aren't essential. Otherwise, this deck is fairly cheap to build and tons of fun to play.

Also, while you may think the Aven Riftw@tcher is a poor substitute for Kitchen Finks, notice that the Riftw@tcher gives life when he leaves play. Use the Barrin to pop him back to your hand and recast him (netting 4 life) or enjoy the 2 life when you sac a False Prophet and exile your opponent's board. Like I said, a fun deck. :-)

9856: Barrin, Master Wizard.author: Aquillion
9856: Barrin, Master Wizard.text_parsed:
Comparing him to Temporal Adept is just sad, especially when you realize that the adapt is theoretically a nameless student of his.

Sure, he doesn't tap, uses colorless mana, and costs one less to activate, but none of those things are even remotely worth sacrificing a permanent for -- and the Adept can bounce all kinds of permanents, not just creatures, which is a really big deal and enables many more combos.

9856: Barrin, Master Wizard.author: TheMurderousKitten
9856: Barrin, Master Wizard.text_parsed: Yes, Barrin should have something more spectacular for his card, but I think people are underestimating the usefulness of this card. My favorite place to use him is in a Jhoira of the Ghitu EDH deck. A good Jhoira deck only requires 2 to 3 mana on the table to function properly. That means that any lands beyond those first few are expendable. And since playing Jhoira is all about stalling until the suspended nastiness hits the table, Barrin is quite useful. He keeps opponents from attacking with big creatures for at least a few turns, which is all Jhoira needs. And as long as you are playing a land each turn, you should have plenty of permanents to sacrifice. Not really a game winning card, but it does have its uses.

9856: Barrin, Master Wizard.author: groglord
9856: Barrin, Master Wizard.text_parsed:
In my commandeer games he usually works well; instead of chump blocking I now have the choice of bouncing your creature, dodge mass revoval for 2 (plus whatever creatures I'm gonna lose anyway), "redirect" removal spells for 2, clear a path for the final blow (cause who needs those lands anymore).

He is only use in specific situations but he has saved me a bunch of times.

9856: Barrin, Master Wizard.author: jfuite
9856: Barrin, Master Wizard.text_parsed: I use Barrin, Master Wizard in a Talrand, Sky Summoner commander deck.  There are plenty of drakes that are getting into trouble anyway, which I can sacrifice to his powerful ability.  His ability does not require tapping, and can be used to target multiple permanents, including planeswalkers.  You can clear your opponents board of defenders by sacrificing your lands for a game-ending attack.  It can be a very good card.
